title: Judge Joe Wapner, of The People's Court, Died at Age 97
text:
Judge Joe Wapner, of The People's Court , Died at Age 97 
He was America's favorite judge. Getty Michael Tran By Peter Wade Feb 26, 2017 Joseph Wapner, best known as the judge on The People's Court, died on Sunday at age 97, according to TMZ . He died in his sleep at home under hospice care after suffering breathing complications. Wapner served for two decades as a judge, as first in a municipal court and later on the Los Angeles Superior Court. After retirement, he became the first judge on The People's Court, a popular TV program. Wapner was a court TV pioneer, without whom there likely would be no Judge Judy , no Judge Mathis , no Divorce Court, no Hot Bench (yes, apparently, that's a thing ). The man spawned an industry that has showcased regular Americans in civil disputes. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The People's Court cases were tried without lawyers by the rules of Small Claims Court, which has a damage limit of $1,500. But Wapner's accomplishments were not limited to the bench. He was a decorated war veteran who earned both a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star for his service in the Pacific during World War II. In one battle, he risked his life to save a fellow soldier who was wounded from being hit by machine gun fire. Most Popular "Everything on the show is real," Wapner told the AP in a 1986 interview. "There's no script, no rehearsal, no retakes. Everything from beginning to end is like a real courtroom, and I personally consider each case as a trial." Wapner became a household name thanks to his tenure on The People's Court, for which he received four daytime Emmy nominations as well as a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame . According to a 1991 Washington Post survey, 54 percent of people could identify Wapner as the judge on The People's Court, whereas only 9 percent of people could name the chief justice of the United States Supreme Court.
